perturbation.original_text: For any Product or Solution sold to any perspective clients introduced by Bravatek registered with COMPANY via email to COMPANY's CEO and delivered through Bravatek or a COMPANY-designated distribution affiliate(s) or sales channel(s), Bravatek will receive a lead-finder fee, to be mutually discussed and finally decided by COMPANY at the range of minimum of 10% to maximum of 20% of project revenue, with an exact fee to be depending upon the overall project sales margin and cost of development and delivery of each project, payable NET 30 days after each client payment on delivered products received at COMPANY's bank account.
perturbation.changed_text: For any Product or Solution sold to any perspective clients introduced by Bravatek registered with COMPANY via email to COMPANY's CEO and delivered through Bravatek or a COMPANY-designated distribution affiliate(s) or sales channel(s), Bravatek will receive a lead-finder fee, to be mutually discussed and finally decided by COMPANY at the range of minimum of 10% to maximum of 20% of project revenue, with an exact fee to be depending upon the overall project sales margin and cost of development and delivery of each project, payable NET 90 days after each client payment on delivered products received at COMPANY's bank account.
perturbation.explanation: Changing the payment term from NET 30 to NET 90 could violate prompt payment laws in some states if the company is a small business. Given this contract applies in Texas, we need to determine if this change violates Texas prompt payment laws.
perturbation.law_explanation: Texas Business and Commerce Code § 28.004 states that payments to small businesses must be made within 30 days of receipt of the invoice. While this contract is between two corporations and it's not explicitly stated that Bravatek is a small business, making the payment term 90 days violates the general spirit and potentially the letter of the law regarding prompt payments to small businesses. It increases the risk of a dispute under the Texas Prompt Payment Act.

perturbation.original_text: The term of this Agreement is twelve (12) months from the date hereof, and will be automatically renewed for one (1) additional twelve month period unless either party shall notify the other in writing of its intention not to renew. Such notice must be given ninety (90) days prior to expiration of the original term.
perturbation.changed_text: The term of this Agreement is twelve (12) months from the date hereof, and will be automatically renewed for one (1) additional twelve month period unless either party shall notify the other in writing of its intention not to renew. Such notice must be given thirty (30) days prior to expiration of the original term.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the non-renewal notice period from 90 days to 30 days might be considered unreasonable under Texas law, especially if it disadvantages one party significantly.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Texas contract law principle of 'Reasonable Notice'
perturbation.law_explanation: While not a specific statute, Texas contract law requires reasonable notice for termination or non-renewal of contracts. Changing the notice period to 30 days, when a 90-day notice was initially agreed upon, is much less favorable for the party that does not wish to automatically renew and creates a scenario where a party has less time to make arrangements. A court could find that 30 days' notice is insufficient and therefore unreasonable under the circumstances. The Business and Commerce Code Section 2.309 speaks to absence of specific time provisions. Here the time provision has changed, but this law explains the principle in general.

perturbation.original_text: For a period of five (5) years after termination of this Agreement, the parties shall treat as confidential all information and take every reasonable precaution and use all reasonable efforts to prevent the unauthorized disclosure of the same.
perturbation.changed_text: For a period of one (1) year after termination of this Agreement, the parties shall treat as confidential all information and take every reasonable precaution and use all reasonable efforts to prevent the unauthorized disclosure of the same.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the confidentiality period from five years to one year may be insufficient to protect trade secrets under Texas law, especially if the information has a longer commercial value or lifespan.
perturbation.law_explanation: Texas Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 134A.002 defines misappropriation of trade secrets. While TUTSA doesn't specify a required confidentiality period, reducing it to one year significantly increases the risk of trade secret misappropriation if the confidential information retains commercial value beyond that period. A one-year term might be deemed inadequate protection, leading to potential legal disputes if confidential information is disclosed after that period and causes harm. The determination of adequate time for protection falls into what would be considered reasonable. While this period of time might be valid, it depends on what constitutes a company trade secret. The second URL is to a document related to trade secret protection in Texas, as it is difficult to find an official document specifically stating the need for a certain amount of time to protect trade secrets.
